message.content: This question requires knowledge about how light interacts with objects, specifically with stained glass. When a beam of sunlight strikes a stained glass window, the colors of the light are separated and refracted, resulting in a beautiful display of hues. Option (A) is incorrect because the colors do not disappear, but rather become more visible. Option (C) is unrelated and not mentioned in the scenario. Option (D) is also unrelated and not mentioned in the scenario.

This question requires basic knowledge about the interaction of light with stained glass. When a beam of sunlight strikes a stained glass window, the glass acts as a prism and refracts the light. This causes the light to separate into its component colors, creating a beautiful display of hues. Option (A) is incorrect because the colors do not disappear, but rather become more vibrant. Option (C) is unrelated to the interaction of sunlight with stained glass. Option (D) is also unrelated because there is no mention of fires being put out.

This question tests our knowledge about the interaction of sunlight with stained glass windows. When a beam of sunlight strikes a stained glass window, the glass acts as a prism and refracts the light, causing the colors to separate and multiply. This is why stained glass windows often have vibrant and multiple hues. Option (A) is incorrect because the colors do not disappear. Option (C) is unrelated to the effects of sunlight on stained glass windows. Option (D) is unrelated to the question and does not describe any known effects of sunlight on stained glass.

Option (A) is incorrect because the colors do not disappear, but rather become more pronounced. Option (C) is unrelated to the effect of sunlight on stained glass.
